deliberation: Checked for metaphors or idioms in the command to buy a potter’s jug and take elders. Although the jug will later become symbolic, in this verse the commands are purely preparatory and descriptive; no figurative language in the wording itself.

Examined references to the Valley of Ben-hinnom and the Harsith Gate. These are geographical/proper names. The act of going out and proclaiming is literal prophetic behavior with no figurative phrasing in this verse.

Looked for metaphors and idioms in the proclamation formula. The key expression is that the ears of everyone who hears will ‘tingle,’ which is a conventional Hebrew idiom for intense shock or horror, not a literal physical symptom.

instances.english_text: such disaster upon this place that the ears of all who hear about it will tingle
target: the hearer’s emotional/psychological reaction to the news of disaster
vehicle: ears tingling from a sudden intense sensation
ground: sudden, sharp, unsettling impact on the hearer
intensity/shock
shared human embodiment (link between body sensation and emotion)
posture: depicts the coming judgment as uniquely horrifying and shocking
instances.explanation: The idiom of ears ‘tingling’ metaphorically expresses the overwhelming shock and horror people will feel when they hear of the coming calamity, exaggerating bodily reaction to convey the extremity of the news.

deliberation: Considered whether ‘have made this place alien’ and ‘filled this place with the blood of the innocent’ are figurative. The killings and bloodshed are real, but the phrase ‘have made this place alien’ conceptualizes the cultic and covenantal distortion of the site as if the place itself had been turned into something foreign.

instances.english_text: and have made this place alien [to Me]
target: the cultic and covenantal status of the site and its worshipers
ground: no longer belonging to its proper owner, estranged and inappropriate
estrangement and otherness
breach of rightful relationship
posture: condemns the site’s worship as completely estranged from YHWH
instances.explanation: The ‘place’ stands metonymically for its cultic use and community, and their idolatrous practices are described metaphorically as making the place ‘foreign,’ signaling estrangement from YHWH as if the area had changed national or covenantal identity.

deliberation: The child sacrifice and building of high places are tragically literal. The figurative element is the closing statement ‘which never came to My mind/heart,’ which uses anthropomorphic metaphor for God’s intentions.

instances.english_text: and which never came to My mind [lit. ‘never arose upon My heart’]
target: God’s will and intention regarding acceptable worship
vehicle: a thought arising in a human heart/mind
ground: what one truly plans or desires is pictured as a thought forming in the heart
intention/desire
shared conceptual link between heart and will
posture: emphatically denies any divine sanction for child sacrifice
instances.explanation: God’s ‘heart’ is used anthropomorphically, and His intention is described in terms of a human thought that might ‘arise’ there. The idiom stresses that such practices were never even remotely within God’s will.

deliberation: Focused on the renaming of the place from Topheth/Valley of Ben-hinnom to ‘Valley of Slaughter.’ This new name is a prophetic, figurative designation that characterizes the valley by its destined function as a place of mass killing.

instances.english_text: but [it shall be called] the Valley of Slaughter
target: the future fate and history of the valley and its people
ground: the place will be filled with killing so that slaughter becomes its defining trait
identity by dominant function/outcome
curse imagery of battlefield devastation
posture: labels the site as under total, bloody judgment
instances.explanation: The prophetic renaming functions metaphorically and metonymically: the valley is defined by the slaughter that will occur there, so the event of mass killing becomes its very name and identity.

deliberation: Identified (1) the verb ‘I will baqqōtî their counsel’ as metaphorical, drawn from ‘emptying out’ a container, also playing on the word for jug; and (2) ‘fall by the sword’ as metonymy where ‘sword’ stands for violent warfare/death in battle.

instances.english_text: And I will frustrate [lit. ‘empty out’] the counsel of Judah and Jerusalem
target: the political and strategic plans of Judah and Jerusalem
vehicle: a container/jug being emptied out or made void
ground: what is emptied is rendered useless and ineffective
nullification/voiding
failure of plans
posture: depicts their counsel as utterly futile under divine judgment
instances.explanation: The verb from the root בק״ק (‘to empty out’) is applied to ‘counsel,’ picturing their plans as if they were a jug being poured out to nothing. This likely plays on the earlier ‘jug’ (בַקְבֻּק) and is both metaphor and paronomastic wordplay.

instances.english_text: I will cause them to fall by the sword before their enemies
target: the violent death of the people in war
ground: sword use is emblematic of warfare and violent death
instrument stands for the whole process of battle
conventional martial idiom
posture: announces their complete defeat in war
instances.explanation: ‘By the sword’ is a standard Hebrew idiom where ‘sword’ stands metonymically for warfare and violent death in battle, not narrowly for a particular blade.

deliberation: Noted two clear figures: (1) the city made ‘a desolation and a hissing,’ where hissing is a gesture standing for derision and horror; and (2) ‘all its wounds,’ which personifies the city as a body afflicted with blows.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשַׂמְתִּי֙ אֶת־הָעִ֣יר הַזֹּ֔את לְשַׁמָּ֖ה וְלִשְׁרֵקָ֑ה כֹּ֚ל עֹבֵ֣ר עָלֶ֔יהָ יִשֹּׁ֥ם וְיִשְׁרֹ֖ק
instances.english_text: I will make this city an object of horror and hissing; everyone who passes by it will be appalled and will hiss
target: the reputation and perception of the devastated city
vehicle: hissing as a gesture of derision or astonished scorn
ground: visible expression of shock, mockery, and dismay
public display of abhorrence
social shaming
posture: presents the city as a warning spectacle to others
instances.explanation: The city is characterized as a ‘hissing,’ where the physical gesture of hissing functions metonymically and metaphorically for the contemptuous and horrified reaction of onlookers.

instances.english_text: and will hiss over all its wounds
target: the various calamities and damages suffered by the city
vehicle: injuries/blows inflicted on a living organism
ground: multiple discrete blows that leave visible marks
accumulated damage and suffering
analogical mapping of city to human body
posture: underscores the city’s condition as grievously and repeatedly struck
instances.explanation: The city is personified as a body covered with ‘wounds,’ i.e., the various disasters that have struck it; observers hiss in astonishment and derision at the extent of its injuries.

deliberation: Considered whether the cannibalism language might be purely figurative. In light of parallel siege-curse texts and historical siege conditions, the text intends literal, though extreme, behavior under famine, not a metaphor. Therefore, no distinct figurative expression is isolated here.

The command for Jeremiah to smash the jug in front of the witnesses is a symbolic act in the narrative, but the wording itself is entirely literal description of the action; the figurative meaning is given explicitly in the next verse.

This verse verbally interprets the sign-act. There is an explicit comparison: ‘So will I smash this people and this city, as one smashes a potter’s vessel,’ making the breaking of a ceramic vessel a simile (and underlying metaphor) for the irreversible shattering of the people and the city.

instances.hebrew_text: כָּ֣כָה אֶשְׁבֹּ֞ר אֶת־הָעָ֤ם הַזֶּה֙ וְאֶת־הָעִ֣יר הַזֹּ֔את כַּאֲשֶׁ֤ר יִשְׁבֹּר֙ אֶת־כְּלִ֣י הַיּוֹצֵ֔ר אֲשֶׁ֛ר לֹא־יוּכַ֥ל לְהֵרָפֵ֖ה עוֹד
instances.english_text: So will I smash this people and this city, as one smashes a potter’s vessel, which can never be mended
target: the destruction of the people of Judah and the city of Jerusalem
vehicle: a potter’s clay vessel smashed beyond repair
ground: once shattered, the object cannot be restored to its prior wholeness
irreversibility and totality of breakage
finality of judgment
posture: emphasizes that the coming judgment will be complete and irreversible
instances.explanation: Using an explicit ‘as’ comparison, God likens His breaking of the people and city to the shattering of a potter’s vessel that cannot be repaired, a vivid hyperbolic simile conveying the total and final nature of the judgment.

deliberation: Here God says He will make ‘this city like Topheth,’ an explicit simile likening Jerusalem as a whole to the infamous, defiled site of burning and burial in the valley.

instances.english_text: I will make this city like Topheth
target: the future state and reputation of Jerusalem
vehicle: Topheth, the polluted site of burning and burial
place of defilement and mass death
ground: both become associated with defilement, burning, and graves
equivalence in cursed status
shared role as emblem of divine wrath
posture: declares that Jerusalem will share the same abominable, cursed character as Topheth
instances.explanation: Topheth stands metonymically for a place of abomination and judgment; Jerusalem is explicitly likened to it, so that the city’s coming fate mirrors the notorious valley.

deliberation: Saw two figures: (1) ‘the houses of Jerusalem and the houses of the kings of Judah shall be like the place Topheth, unclean’—another simile extending the Topheth image; (2) ‘the whole host of heaven’ as a standard metaphor, picturing celestial bodies/divine beings as an army/host.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָי֞וּ בָּתֵּ֣י יְרוּשָׁלַ֗͏ִם וּבָתֵּי֙ מַלְכֵ֣י יְהוּדָ֔ה כִּמְק֥וֹם הַתֹּ֖פֶת הַטְּמֵאִ֑ים
instances.english_text: the houses of Jerusalem and the houses of the kings of Judah shall be impure, like that place Topheth
target: the ritual and moral status of Jerusalem’s and the kings’ houses
vehicle: Topheth as an unclean, defiled cultic site
place characterized by impurity and abomination
ground: both are made unclean by idolatrous rites and contact with death
shared impurity and abominable usage
parity in defiled status
posture: equates even royal and urban houses with the most defiled site
instances.explanation: The houses are explicitly likened to Topheth; Topheth itself functions metonymically for extreme cultic defilement, so the simile transfers that polluted identity to every house involved in illicit worship.

instances.english_text: to the whole host of heaven
vehicle: a ‘host’ or army arrayed in ranks
ground: a numerous, organized group under an implied commander
ordered multiplicity
regimented structure attributed to celestial phenomena
posture: depicts the heavenly bodies as an organized host wrongly receiving worship
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘host of heaven’ metaphorically and metonymically portrays the array of celestial bodies (and perhaps associated beings) as a military host, an ‘army’ in the sky, a conventional biblical image for the ordered multiplicity of the heavens.

deliberation: Narrative description of Jeremiah’s movements—from Topheth to the court of the House of YHWH—and his speaking to the people. ‘House of YHWH’ is a standard designation for the temple but also literally a building; no distinct figurative expression is foregrounded here.
The idiom ‘they have stiffened their necks’ is a well-known metaphor for stubbornness, picturing people as draft animals resisting the yoke. This is the key figurative expression in the verse.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּ֤י הִקְשׁוּ֙ אֶת־עׇרְפָּ֔ם לְבִלְתִּ֖י שְׁמ֥וֹעַ אֶת־דְּבָרָֽי
instances.english_text: for they have stiffened their necks so as not to heed My words
target: the people’s obstinate refusal to obey God
vehicle: an animal stiffening its neck against a yoke
ground: unyielding resistance to guidance and control
refusal to submit
analogy between physical rigidity and moral stubbornness
posture: condemns their disobedience as willful and animal-like obstinacy
instances.explanation: The neck (a body part, metonymy for the whole person) is pictured as deliberately stiffened like that of a draft animal resisting the yoke, a vivid metaphor for hardened, unteachable refusal to listen to God.
